publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-1924 Rob Gibson: Eco-friendly Architecture—That the Parliament congratulates the entrants and finalists in the annual architectural prize competition organised by the Royal Incorporation of Architects in Scotland (RIAS); welcomes a secure future for the competition; notes that the judges chose the new school campus at St Aloysius’ College in Glasgow as a well-deserved winner, but commends the public’s choice in an on-line poll of a house constructed of wood for Danish artist Lotte Glob which is sited near Loch Eriboll in Sutherland; commends its design by Aberdeen architect Gökay Deveci, who lectures in architectural design at the Scott Sutherland School at The Robert Gordon University, and encourages clients throughout Scotland to commission many more eco-friendly designs for homes and workplaces that are made from local materials, in particular from locally-sourced wood from Scottish forests.

S2M-1924 Eco-friendly Architecture (lodged on 1 November 2004) Michael Matheson*, Jim Mather*, Roseanna Cunningham*, Mr Adam Ingram*, Eleanor Scott*, Ms Sandra White*, Mr Stewart Maxwell*, Bruce Crawford*, Frances Curran*, Patrick Harvie*
S2M-1924 Eco-friendly Architecture (lodged on 1 November 2004) Mr Jamie Stone*, Robin Harper*, Chris Ballance*, Mary Scanlon*, Richard Lochhead*, Donald Gorrie*
S2M-1924 Eco-friendly Architecture (lodged on 1 November 2004) Mr Mark Ruskell*

S2M-1924 Rob Gibson: Eco-friendly Architecture—That the Parliament congratulates the entrants and finalists in the annual architectural prize competition organised by the Royal Incorporation of Architects in Scotland (RIAS); welcomes a secure future for the competition; notes that the judges chose the new school campus at St Aloysius’ College in Glasgow as a well-deserved winner, but commends the public’s choice in an on-line poll of a house constructed of wood for Danish artist Lotte Glob which is sited near Loch Eriboll in Sutherland; commends its design by Aberdeen architect Gökay Deveci, who lectures in architectural design at the Scott Sutherland School at The Robert Gordon University, and encourages clients throughout Scotland to commission many more eco-friendly designs for homes and workplaces that are made from local materials, in particular from locally-sourced wood from Scottish forests. Supported by: Michael Matheson, Jim Mather, Roseanna Cunningham, Mr Adam Ingram, Eleanor Scott, Ms Sandra White, Mr Stewart Maxwell, Bruce Crawford, Frances Curran, Patrick Harvie, Mr Jamie Stone, Robin Harper, Chris Ballance, Mary Scanlon, Richard Lochhead, Donald Gorrie, Mr Mark Ruskell
S2M-1924 Eco-friendly Architecture (lodged on 1 November 2004) Nora Radcliffe*
S2M-1924 Eco-friendly Architecture (lodged on 1 November 2004) Linda Fabiani*
